title: Chicago XIV (14)
description:
Okay, well this marks the end of Chicago&#039;s run on Columbia Records.  Columbia was pretty disappointed with Chicago&#039;s performance in its last few albums.  Here&#039;s why, their highest chart ratings:

IX:  #1
X:  #1
XI:  #6
Hot Streets:  #12
13:  #83
14:  #71

Owch.  Plus the only single from 13 reached a height of #83.  And 14 #56.

But there are some good things about this album.  It is pared back, not quite as Disco.  It is also the last Donnie Dacus album which is good -- because he sucks.  And Laudir, the Brazilian percussionist who jumps up and down playing the marimba took his funky name and hair back to South America.

Altogether, this album isn&#039;t bad.  It&#039;s a necessary stepping stone and one that probably spurred the band to come back, on another label, with three successive knockouts.

This album contains:


Manipulation

Upon Arrival

Song for You

Where Did the Lovin Go

Birthday Boy

Hold On

Overnight Cafe

Thunder and Lightning

I&#039;d Rather Be Rich

The American Dream

Doin&#039; Business

Live it Up

Soldier of Fortune



If you listen carefully, you can hear the loons.
